item.title: Demis Hassabis & John Jumper awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry
item.content:encoded: The award recognizes their work developing AlphaFold, a groundbreaking AI system that predicts the 3D structure of proteins from their amino acid sequences.

item.title: How AlphaChip transformed computer chip design
item.content:encoded: Our AI method has accelerated and optimized chip design, and its superhuman chip layouts are used in hardware around the world.

item.title: Updated production-ready Gemini models, reduced 1.5 Pro pricing, increased rate limits, and more
item.content:encoded: We’re releasing two updated production-ready Gemini models

item.title: Empowering YouTube creators with generative AI
item.content:encoded: New video generation technology in YouTube Shorts will help millions of people realize their creative vision

item.title: Our latest advances in robot dexterity
item.content:encoded: Two new AI systems, ALOHA Unleashed and DemoStart, help robots learn to perform complex tasks that require dexterous movement

item.title: AlphaProteo generates novel proteins for biology and health research
item.content:encoded: New AI system designs proteins that successfully bind to target molecules, with potential for advancing drug design, disease understanding and more.

item.title: FermiNet: Quantum physics and chemistry from first principles
item.content:encoded: Using deep learning to solve fundamental problems in computational quantum chemistry and explore how matter interacts with light

item.title: A new generation of African talent brings cutting-edge AI to scientific challenges
item.content:encoded: Food security, healthcare and exploring the cosmos are among the ways students of a new pan-African Master’s program aspire to apply AI

item.title: Mapping the misuse of generative AI
item.content:encoded: New research analyzes the misuse of multimodal generative AI today, in order to help build safer and more responsible technologies.

item.title: Gemma Scope: helping the safety community shed light on the inner workings of language models
item.content:encoded: Announcing a comprehensive, open suite of sparse autoencoders for language model interpretability.

item.title: AI achieves silver-medal standard solving International Mathematical Olympiad problems
item.content:encoded: Breakthrough models AlphaProof and AlphaGeometry 2 solve advanced reasoning problems in mathematics

item.title: Google DeepMind at ICML 2024
item.content:encoded: Exploring AGI, the challenges of scaling and the future of multimodal generative AI

item.title: Generating audio for video
item.content:encoded: Video-to-audio research uses video pixels and text prompts to generate rich soundtracks

item.title: Looking ahead to the AI Seoul Summit
item.content:encoded: How summits in Seoul, France and beyond can galvanize international cooperation on frontier AI safety

item.title: Introducing the Frontier Safety Framework
item.content:encoded: Our approach to analyzing and mitigating future risks posed by advanced AI models

item.title: Gemini系列模型更新：引入1.5 Flash与Project Astra
item.content:encoded:
Gemini系列模型更新，包括新发布的1.5 Flash和未来AI助手项目Astra。



摘要： 我们正在对Gemini系列模型进行一系列更新，重点推出了1.5 Flash新型号。这款轻量级模型专注于速度与效率，旨在满足快速生产和响应需求。此外，我们还提出了Project Astra，这是我们对未来AI助手的愿景，期待能够充分发挥AI在提升用户体验和效率方面的潜力。通过这些更新，我们希望为用户提供更强大、更灵活的AI工具，使其在各个应用场景中都能达到最佳表现。



使用 gpt-4o-mini 生成

查看原文

item.title: 介绍Veo和Imagen 3：高端视频与图像生成模型
item.content:encoded:
我们推出了Veo和Imagen 3模型，并分享了新的音乐AI沙盒录音示范。



摘要： 我们很高兴地介绍Veo，这是我们生成高分辨率视频的最强大模型。Veo的推出将为内容创作者和开发者提供丰富的工具，帮助他们更轻松地创建精美的视频内容。此外，我们还推出了Imagen 3，这是我们目前最高质量的文本到图像模型，能够以卓越的视觉表现将文字转化为逼真的图像。为了展示这两个新模型的强大功能，我们分享了一些通过我们的音乐AI沙盒创造的新的示范录音，让用户能够感受到先进AI技术在多媒体创作中的应用潜力。这些新工具的发布，无疑将推动创意产业的进一步发展。



使用 gpt-4o-mini 生成

查看原文

item.title: Watermarking AI-generated text and video with SynthID
item.content:encoded: Announcing our novel watermarking method for AI-generated text and video, and how we’re bringing SynthID to key Google products

item.title: AlphaFold 3 predicts the structure and interactions of all of life’s molecules
item.content:encoded: Introducing a new AI model developed by Google DeepMind and Isomorphic Labs.

item.title: TacticAI: an AI assistant for football tactics
item.content:encoded: As part of our multi-year collaboration with Liverpool FC, we develop a full AI system that can advise coaches on corner kicks

item.title: A generalist AI agent for 3D virtual environments
item.content:encoded: Introducing SIMA, a Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent

item.title: Gemma: Introducing new state-of-the-art open models
item.content:encoded: Gemma is built for responsible AI development from the same research and technology used to create Gemini models.

item.title: Our next-generation model: Gemini 1.5
item.content:encoded: The model delivers dramatically enhanced performance, with a breakthrough in long-context understanding across modalities.

item.title: The next chapter of our Gemini era
item.content:encoded: We're bringing Gemini to more Google products

item.title: AlphaGeometry: An Olympiad-level AI system for geometry
item.content:encoded: Advancing AI reasoning in mathematics

item.title: Shaping the future of advanced robotics
item.content:encoded: Introducing AutoRT, SARA-RT, and RT-Trajectory

item.title: Images altered to trick machine vision can influence humans too
item.content:encoded: In a series of experiments published in Nature Communications, we found evidence that human judgments are indeed systematically influenced by adversarial perturbations.

item.title: 2023: A Year of Groundbreaking Advances in AI and Computing
item.content:encoded: This has been a year of incredible progress in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) research and its practical applications.

item.title: FunSearch: Making new discoveries in mathematical sciences using Large Language Models
item.content:encoded: In a paper published in Nature, we introduce FunSearch, a method for searching for “functions” written in computer code, and find new solutions in mathematics and computer science. FunSearch works by pairing a pre-trained LLM, whose goal is to provide creative solutions in the form of computer code, with an automated “evaluator”, which guards against hallucinations and incorrect ideas.

item.title: Google DeepMind at NeurIPS 2023
item.content:encoded: The Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS) is the largest artificial intelligence (AI) conference in the world. NeurIPS 2023 will be taking place December 10-16 in New Orleans, USA.Teams from across Google DeepMind are presenting more than 150 papers at the main conference and workshops.

item.title: Introducing Gemini: our largest and most capable AI model
item.content:encoded: Making AI more helpful for everyone

item.title: Millions of new materials discovered with deep learning
item.content:encoded: We share the discovery of 2.2 million new crystals – equivalent to nearly 800 years’ worth of knowledge. We introduce Graph Networks for Materials Exploration (GNoME), our new deep learning tool that dramatically increases the speed and efficiency of discovery by predicting the stability of new materials.

item.title: Transforming the future of music creation
item.content:encoded: Announcing our most advanced music generation model and two new AI experiments, designed to open a new playground for creativity

item.title: Empowering the next generation for an AI-enabled world
item.content:encoded: Experience AI's course and resources are expanding on a global scale

item.title: GraphCast: AI model for faster and more accurate global weather forecasting
item.content:encoded: We introduce GraphCast, a state-of-the-art AI model able to make medium-range weather forecasts with unprecedented accuracy

item.title: A glimpse of the next generation of AlphaFold
item.content:encoded: Progress update: Our latest AlphaFold model shows significantly improved accuracy and expands coverage beyond proteins to other biological molecules, including ligands.

item.title: Evaluating social and ethical risks from generative AI
item.content:encoded: Introducing a context-based framework for comprehensively evaluating the social and ethical risks of AI systems

item.title: Scaling up learning across many different robot types
item.content:encoded: Robots are great specialists, but poor generalists. Typically, you have to train a model for each task, robot, and environment. Changing a single variable often requires starting from scratch. But what if we could combine the knowledge across robotics and create a way to train a general-purpose robot?

item.title: A catalogue of genetic mutations to help pinpoint the cause of diseases
item.content:encoded: New AI tool classifies the effects of 71 million ‘missense’ mutations.

item.title: Identifying AI-generated images with SynthID
item.content:encoded: New tool helps watermark and identify synthetic images created by Imagen

item.title: RT-2: New model translates vision and language into action
item.content:encoded: Robotic Transformer 2 (RT-2) is a novel vision-language-action (VLA) model that learns from both web and robotics data, and translates this knowledge into generalised instructions for robotic control.

item.title: Using AI to fight climate change
item.content:encoded: AI is a powerful technology that will transform our future, so how can we best apply it to help combat climate change and find sustainable solutions?

item.title: Google DeepMind’s latest research at ICML 2023
item.content:encoded: Exploring AI safety, adaptability, and efficiency for the real world

item.title: Developing reliable AI tools for healthcare
item.content:encoded: We’ve published our joint paper with Google Research in Nature Medicine, which proposes CoDoC (Complementarity-driven Deferral-to-Clinical Workflow), an AI system that learns when to rely on predictive AI tools or defer to a clinician for the most accurate interpretation of medical images.

item.title: Exploring institutions for global AI governance
item.content:encoded: New white paper investigates models and functions of international institutions that could help manage opportunities and mitigate risks of advanced AI.

item.title: RoboCat: A self-improving robotic agent
item.content:encoded: Robots are quickly becoming part of our everyday lives, but they’re often only programmed to perform specific tasks well. While harnessing recent advances in AI could lead to robots that could help in many more ways, progress in building general-purpose robots is slower in part because of the time needed to collect real-world training data. Our latest paper introduces a self-improving AI agent for robotics, RoboCat, that learns to perform a variety of tasks across different arms, and then self-generates new training data to improve its technique.

item.title: YouTube: Enhancing the user experience
item.content:encoded: It’s all about using our technology and research to help enrich people’s lives. Like YouTube — and its mission to give everyone a voice and show them the world.

item.title: Google Cloud: Driving digital transformation
item.content:encoded: Google Cloud empowers organizations to digitally transform themselves into smarter businesses. It offers cloud computing, data analytics, and the latest artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning tools.

item.title: MuZero, AlphaZero, and AlphaDev: Optimizing computer systems
item.content:encoded: How MuZero, AlphaZero, and AlphaDev are optimizing the computing ecosystem that powers our world of devices.

item.title: AlphaDev discovers faster sorting algorithms
item.content:encoded: New algorithms will transform the foundations of computing

item.title: An early warning system for novel AI risks
item.content:encoded: New research proposes a framework for evaluating general-purpose models against novel threats

item.title: DeepMind’s latest research at ICLR 2023
item.content:encoded: Next week marks the start of the 11th International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), taking place 1-5 May in Kigali, Rwanda. This will be the first major artificial intelligence (AI) conference to be hosted in Africa and the first in-person event since the start of the pandemic. Researchers from around the world will gather to share their cutting-edge work in deep learning spanning the fields of AI, statistics and data science, and applications including machine vision, gaming and robotics. We’re proud to support the conference as a Diamond sponsor and DEI champion.

item.title: How can we build human values into AI?
item.content:encoded: Drawing from philosophy to identify fair principles for ethical AI...

item.title: Announcing Google DeepMind
item.content:encoded: DeepMind and the Brain team from Google Research will join forces to accelerate progress towards a world in which AI helps solve the biggest challenges facing humanity.

item.title: Competitive programming with AlphaCode
item.content:encoded: Solving novel problems and setting a new milestone in competitive programming.

item.title: AI for the board game Diplomacy
item.content:encoded: Successful communication and cooperation have been crucial for helping societies advance throughout history. The closed environments of board games can serve as a sandbox for modelling and investigating interaction and communication – and we can learn a lot from playing them. In our recent paper, published today in Nature Communications, we show how artificial agents can use communication to better cooperate in the board game Diplomacy, a vibrant domain in artificial intelligence (AI) research, known for its focus on alliance building.

item.title: Mastering Stratego, the classic game of imperfect information
item.content:encoded: Game-playing artificial intelligence (AI) systems have advanced to a new frontier.

item.title: DeepMind’s latest research at NeurIPS 2022
item.content:encoded: NeurIPS is the world’s largest conference in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), and we’re proud to support the event as Diamond sponsors, helping foster the exchange of research advances in the AI and ML community. Teams from across DeepMind are presenting 47 papers, including 35 external collaborations in virtual panels and poster sessions.

item.title: Building interactive agents in video game worlds
item.content:encoded: Most artificial intelligence (AI) researchers now believe that writing computer code which can capture the nuances of situated interactions is impossible. Alternatively, modern machine learning (ML) researchers have focused on learning about these types of interactions from data. To explore these learning-based approaches and quickly build agents that can make sense of human instructions and safely perform actions in open-ended conditions, we created a research framework within a video game environment.Today, we’re publishing a paper [INSERT LINK] and collection of videos, showing our early steps in building video game AIs that can understand fuzzy human concepts – and therefore, can begin to interact with people on their own terms.

item.title: Benchmarking the next generation of never-ending learners
item.content:encoded: Learning how to build upon knowledge by tapping 30 years of computer vision research

item.title: Best practices for data enrichment
item.content:encoded: Building a responsible approach to data collection with the Partnership on AI...

item.title: The pursuit of AI education—past, present, and future
item.content:encoded: Meet Sylvia Christie, our education partnerships manager who’s played a leading role in expanding our scholarship programme, which is marking its five-year anniversary.

item.title: Stopping malaria in its tracks
item.content:encoded: Developing a vaccine that could save hundreds of thousands of lives

item.title: Measuring perception in AI models
item.content:encoded: Perception – the process of experiencing the world through senses – is a significant part of intelligence. And building agents with human-level perceptual understanding of the world is a central but challenging task, which is becoming increasingly important in robotics, self-driving cars, personal assistants, medical imaging, and more. So today, we’re introducing the Perception Test, a multimodal benchmark using real-world videos to help evaluate the perception capabilities of a model.

item.title: How undesired goals can arise with correct rewards
item.content:encoded: As we build increasingly advanced artificial intelligence (AI) systems, we want to make sure they don’t pursue undesired goals. Such behaviour in an AI agent is often the result of specification gaming – exploiting a poor choice of what they are rewarded for. In our latest paper, we explore a more subtle mechanism by which AI systems may unintentionally learn to pursue undesired goals: goal misgeneralisation (GMG). GMG occurs when a system's capabilities generalise successfully but its goal does not generalise as desired, so the system competently pursues the wrong goal. Crucially, in contrast to specification gaming, GMG can occur even when the AI system is trained with a correct specification.

item.title: Discovering novel algorithms with AlphaTensor
item.content:encoded: In our paper, published today in Nature, we introduce AlphaTensor, the first artificial intelligence (AI) system for discovering novel, efficient, and provably correct algorithms for fundamental tasks such as matrix multiplication. This sheds light on a 50-year-old open question in mathematics about finding the fastest way to multiply two matrices. This paper is a stepping stone in DeepMind’s mission to advance science and unlock the most fundamental problems using AI. Our system, AlphaTensor, builds upon AlphaZero, an agent that has shown superhuman performance on board games, like chess, Go and shogi, and this work shows the journey of AlphaZero from playing games to tackling unsolved mathematical problems for the first time.

item.title: Fighting osteoporosis before it starts
item.content:encoded: Detecting signs of disease before bones start to break

item.title: Understanding the faulty proteins linked to cancer and autism
item.content:encoded: Helping uncover how protein mutations cause diseases and disorders

item.title: Supporting the next generation of AI leaders
item.content:encoded: We’re partnering with six education charities and social enterprises in the United Kingdom (UK) to co-create a bespoke education programme to help tackle the gaps in STEM education and boost existing programmes.

item.title: Solving the mystery of how an ancient bird went extinct
item.content:encoded: Creating a tool to study extinct species from 50,000 years ago

item.title: Building safer dialogue agents
item.content:encoded: In our latest paper, we introduce Sparrow – a dialogue agent that’s useful and reduces the risk of unsafe and inappropriate answers. Our agent is designed to talk with a user, answer questions, and search the internet using Google when it’s helpful to look up evidence to inform its responses.

item.title: Targeting early-onset Parkinson’s with AI
item.content:encoded: Predictions that pave the way to new treatments

item.title: How our principles helped define AlphaFold’s release
item.content:encoded: Our Operating Principles have come to define both our commitment to prioritising widespread benefit, as well as the areas of research and applications we refuse to pursue. These principles have been at the heart of our decision making since DeepMind was founded, and continue to be refined as the AI landscape changes and grows. They are designed for our role as a research-driven science company and consistent with Google’s AI principles.

item.title: Maximising the impact of our breakthroughs
item.content:encoded: Colin, CBO at DeepMind, discusses collaborations with Alphabet and how we integrate ethics, accountability, and safety into everything we do.

item.title: My journey from DeepMind intern to mentor
item.content:encoded: Former intern turned intern manager, Richard Everett, describes his journey to DeepMind, sharing tips and advice for aspiring DeepMinders. The 2023 internship applications will open on the 16th September, please visit https://dpmd.ai/internshipsatdeepmind for more information.

item.title: In conversation with AI: building better language models
item.content:encoded: Our new paper, In conversation with AI: aligning language models with human values, explores a different approach, asking what successful communication between humans and an artificial conversational agent might look like and what values should guide conversation in these contexts.

item.title: From motor control to embodied intelligence
item.content:encoded: Using human and animal motions to teach robots to dribble a ball, and simulated humanoid characters to carry boxes and play football

item.title: Advancing conservation with AI-based facial recognition of turtles
item.content:encoded: We came across Zindi – a dedicated partner with complementary goals – who are the largest community of African data scientists and host competitions that focus on solving Africa’s most pressing problems. Our Science team’s Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DE&I) team worked with Zindi to identify a scientific challenge that could help advance conservation efforts and grow involvement in AI. Inspired by Zindi’s bounding box turtle challenge, we landed on a project with the potential for real impact: turtle facial recognition.

item.title: Discovering when an agent is present in a system
item.content:encoded: We want to build safe, aligned artificial general intelligence (AGI) systems that pursue the intended goals of its designers. Causal influence diagrams (CIDs) are a way to model decision-making situations that allow us to reason about agent incentives. By relating training setups to the incentives that shape agent behaviour, CIDs help illuminate potential risks before training an agent and can inspire better agent designs. But how do we know when a CID is an accurate model of a training setup?

item.title: Realising scientists are the real superheroes
item.content:encoded: Meet Edgar Duéñez-Guzmán, a research engineer on our Multi-Agent Research team who’s drawing on knowledge of game theory, computer science, and social evolution to get AI agents working better together.

item.title: The race to cure a billion people from a deadly parasitic disease
item.content:encoded: Accelerating the search for life saving leishmaniasis treatments

item.title: Tracing the evolution of proteins back to the origin of life
item.content:encoded: Looking into a protein’s past to unlock the mysteries of life itself

item.title: How the honeybee could help protect species around the world
item.content:encoded: New insights into immunity to help protect the world’s flora

item.title: AlphaFold transforms biology for millions around the world
item.content:encoded: Big data that leads to discoveries that benefit everyone

item.title: Advancing discovery of better drugs and medicine
item.content:encoded: Researchers are designing more effective drugs than ever before

item.title: Creating plastic-eating enzymes that could save us from pollution
item.content:encoded: Helping plastics become 100% recyclable

item.title: AlphaFold unlocks one of the greatest puzzles in biology
item.content:encoded: Piecing together one of the largest molecular structures in human cells

item.title: Accelerating the race against antibiotic resistance
item.content:encoded: Unlocking a decade of data in minutes to help beat antibiotic resistance

item.title: AlphaFold reveals the structure of the protein universe
item.content:encoded: Today, in partnership with EMBL’s European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI), we’re now releasing predicted structures for nearly all catalogued proteins known to science, which will expand the AlphaFold DB by over 200x - from nearly 1 million structures to over 200 million structures - with the potential to dramatically increase our understanding of biology.

item.title: Putting the power of AlphaFold into the world’s hands
item.content:encoded: When we announced AlphaFold 2 last December, it was hailed as a solution to the 50-year old protein folding problem. Last week, we published the scientific paper and source code explaining how we created this highly innovative system, and today we’re sharing high-quality predictions for the shape of every single protein in the human body, as well as for the proteins of 20 additional organisms that scientists rely on for their research.

item.title: The virtuous cycle of AI research
item.content:encoded: We recently caught up with Petar Veličković, a research scientist at DeepMind. Along with his co-authors, Petar is presenting his paper The CLRS Algorithmic Reasoning Benchmark at ICML 2022 in Baltimore, Maryland, USA.

item.title: Perceiver AR: general-purpose, long-context autoregressive generation
item.content:encoded: We develop Perceiver AR, an autoregressive, modality-agnostic architecture which uses cross-attention to map long-range inputs to a small number of latents while also maintaining end-to-end causal masking. Perceiver AR can directly attend to over a hundred thousand tokens, enabling practical long-context density estimation without the need for hand-crafted sparsity patterns or memory mechanisms.

item.title: DeepMind’s latest research at ICML 2022
item.content:encoded: Starting this weekend, the thirty-ninth International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML 2022) is meeting from 17-23 July, 2022 at the Baltimore Convention Center in Maryland, USA, and will be running as a hybrid event. Researchers working across artificial intelligence, data science, machine vision, computational biology, speech recognition, and more are presenting and publishing their cutting-edge work in machine learning.

item.title: Intuitive physics learning in a deep-learning model inspired by developmental psychology
item.content:encoded: Despite significant effort, current AI systems pale in their understanding of intuitive physics, in comparison to even very young children. In the present work, we address this AI problem, specifically by drawing on the field of developmental psychology.

item.title: Human-centred mechanism design with Democratic AI
item.content:encoded: In our recent paper, published in Nature Human Behaviour, we provide a proof-of-concept demonstration that deep reinforcement learning (RL) can be used to find economic policies that people will vote for by majority in a simple game. The paper thus addresses a key challenge in AI research - how to train AI systems that align with human values.

item.title: Leading a movement to strengthen machine learning in Africa
item.content:encoded: Avishkar Bhoopchand, a research engineer on the Game Theory and Multi-agent team, shares his journey to DeepMind and how he’s working to raise the profile of deep learning across Africa.

item.title: BYOL-Explore: Exploration with Bootstrapped Prediction
item.content:encoded: We present BYOL-Explore, a conceptually simple yet general approach for curiosity-driven exploration in visually-complex environments. BYOL-Explore learns a world representation, the world dynamics, and an exploration policy all-together by optimizing a single prediction loss in the latent space with no additional auxiliary objective. We show that BYOL-Explore is effective in DM-HARD-8, a challenging partially-observable continuous-action hard-exploration benchmark with visually-rich 3-D environments.

item.title: Unlocking High-Accuracy Differentially Private Image Classification through Scale
item.content:encoded: According to empirical evidence from prior works, utility degradation in DP-SGD becomes more severe on larger neural network models – including the ones regularly used to achieve the best performance on challenging image classification benchmarks. Our work investigates this phenomenon and proposes a series of simple modifications to both the training procedure and model architecture, yielding a significant improvement on the accuracy of DP training on standard image classification benchmarks.
